section.text: While root position and first inversion triads can be used freely, second inversion usually occurs only in three situations.
Like first inversion, second inversion may be used to smooth out a bass line.
Look at the above example - notice the movement of the bass line.
By placing the V chord in second inversion, the bass line moves by step and becomes smooth.
When used in this fashion, a second inversion triad is called a passing six-four chord.
Second inversion may also be used to straighten a bass line.
Look at the above example - notice how the bass line jumps up to the F and then returns back to C.
By placing the IV chord in second inversion, all movement in the bass line is eliminated.
When used in this fashion, a second inversion triad is called a pedal six-four chord.
The cadential six-four chord is the final and most noticeable use of second inversion.
In this form, the second inversion triad preceeds a V chord in a cadence. Often, the cadence will sound stronger due to the cadential six-four's presence.
On the chord progression chart, the cadential six-four occurs in between a predominant and dominant.
